facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 899 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 14, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4136 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 899 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 14, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4136 of 1964.

facts.text: Gokal Chand was the first respondent and a tenant of shop No. 34/2, Dispensary Road, Dehra Dun.

anchor.surface_text: Gokal Chand--first respondent in this appeal- was a tenant of shop No. 34/2, Dispensary Road, Dehra Dun, which belongs to Munni Devi--the first appellant in this appeal.

facts.text: Shop No. 34/2, Dispensary Road, Dehra Dun belongs to Munni Devi, the first appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Gokal Chand--first respondent in this appeal- was a tenant of shop No. 34/2, Dispensary Road, Dehra Dun, which belongs to Munni Devi--the first appellant in this appeal.

facts.text: Munni Devi applied to the Rent Control Eviction Officer, Dehra Dun, for an order of ejectment against Gokal Chand on the plea of default in paying rent.

anchor.surface_text: Munni Devi applied to the Rent Control Eviction Officer. Dehra Dun, for an order in ejectment on the plea that Gokal Chand had companymitted default in paying rent.

facts.text: The C.E. Officer passed an order observing that the tenant did not lead any evidence to show that he had vacated the shop, that the tenant was not in occupation, and had let it out to one Alladia.

anchor.surface_text: The C. E. Officer passed an order observing that the tenant did number lead any evidence to show that he had number vacated the shop and it was clear on the evidence that the tenant was number in occupation of the shop and had let it out to one Alladia.

facts.text: The R.C.E. Officer declared the shop vacant.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly declared that the shop was vacant. The R.C. E. Officer allotted the shop to Kishorilal.

facts.text: The R.C.E. Officer allotted the shop to Kishorilal.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly declared that the shop was vacant. The R.C. E. Officer allotted the shop to Kishorilal. Kishorilal then applied to the R,C. E. Officer that the shop allotted to him was in the illegal occupation of Rawel Chand s o Gokal Chand.

facts.text: Kishorilal applied to the R.C.E. Officer stating that the shop allotted to him was in illegal occupation of Rawel Chand son of Gokal Chand.

anchor.surface_text: Kishorilal then applied to the R,C. E. Officer that the shop allotted to him was in the illegal occupation of Rawel Chand s o Gokal Chand.

facts.text: On May 22, 1957, the R.C.E. Officer declared that Gokal Chand the previous tenant had vacated the shop and Rawel Chand was in illegal occupation.

anchor.surface_text: On May 22, 1957, the R.C. E. Officer declared that Gokal Chand the previous tenant had vacated the shop. and that Rawel Chand was in illegal occupation of the shop.

facts.text: The R.C.E. Officer issued a notice under s. 7A(3) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly issued a numberice under s. 7A  3  of the Act. Gokal Chand then filed a civil suit in the Court of the Munsif. Dehra Dun,

facts.text: Gokal Chand filed a civil suit in the Court of the Munsif, Dehra Dun, for declaration that he was an allottee and tenant of the shop and in possession in that capacity.

anchor.surface_text: Gokal Chand then filed a civil suit in the Court of the Munsif. Dehra Dun, for a declaration that he was an allottee and a tenant of the shop and that he was in possession in that capacity.

facts.text: Munni Devi and Kishorilal were impleaded as party defendants in Gokal Chand's suit.

anchor.surface_text: To that suit were impleaded Munni Devi and Kishorilal as party defendants. The Trial Court held that Gokal Chand had at numbertime vacated the shop, numberr was his tenancy terminated.

facts.text: The Trial Court held that Gokal Chand had at no time vacated the shop nor was his tenancy terminated.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that Gokal Chand had at numbertime vacated the shop, numberr was his tenancy terminated. He accordingly made an order declaring that Gokal Chand was an allottee and a tenant of the shop.

facts.text: The Trial Court declared Gokal Chand an allottee and tenant entitled to remain in occupation.

anchor.surface_text: He accordingly made an order declaring that Gokal Chand was an allottee and a tenant of the shop. and was entitled to remain in occupation of the same.

facts.text: Appeal against the Trial Court's order to the District Court was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against that order to the District Court was dismissed. A second appeal to the High Court was also unsuccessful.

facts.text: Second appeal to the High Court was unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: A second appeal to the High Court was also unsuccessful. In this appeal with special leave, companynsel for Munni Devi and Kishorilal urges that the order of the civil companyrt was without jurisdiction.

facts.text: The judgment is delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Gokal Chand--first respondent in this appeal- was a tenant of shop No. 34/2, Dispensary Road, Dehra Dun,

facts.text: Yogeshwar Prasad and Harder Singh appeared for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Yogeshwar Prasad and Harder Singh, for the appellants. N. Anand, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: N. Anand appeared for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: N. Anand, for the respondents. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Gokal Chand--first respondent in this appeal- was a tenant of shop No. 34/2,

facts.text: Munni Devi applied for ejectment against Gokal Chand on plea of default in rent.

anchor.surface_text: Munni Devi applied for an order in ejectment against Gokal Chand on the. plea that he had companymitted default in paying rent.

facts.text: R.C.E. Officer held that Gokal Chand had vacated the premises and inducted a sub-tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The R.C. E. Officer held that Gokal Chand had vacated the premise and had inducted a sub-tenant.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated May 14, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 4136 of 1964.
Section 3 of the U.P.  Temporary  Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 194-7, imposes certain restrictions on eviction of tenants.

concepts.interpretation: Imposes restrictions on eviction of tenants.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 7 1  a  it is provided Every landlord shall, within 7 days after an accommodation becomes vacant by his ceasing to occupy it or by the tenant vacting it or otherwise ceasing to occupy it or by termination of a tenancy or by release from requisition or in any other manner whatsoever, give numberice of the vacancy in Writing to the District Magistrate. Sub-sections  2   3  of s. 7 provide The District Magistrate may by general or special order require a landlord to let or number to let to any person any accommodation which is or has fallen vacant or is about to fall vacant. No tenant shall sub-let any portion of the accommodation in his tenancy except with the permission in writing of the landlord and of the District Magistrate previously X X obtained.

concepts.interpretation: Requires notice of vacancy, empowers District Magistrate to allot, prohibits sub-letting without permission.

concepts.unlisted_description: Power to evict unauthorized occupants after allotment order

anchor.surface_text: Section 7A which was added by Act 24 of 1952 provides, in so far as it is material Where in pursuance of an order of the District Magistrate under sub-section  2  of section 7, the vacancy of any accommodation is require. d to. be reported and is number reported, or where an order requiring any accommodation to be let or number to be let has been duly passed under sub-section  2  of Section 7 and the District Magistrate believes or has reason to believe that any person has in companytravention of the said order, occupied the accommodation or any part thereof, he may call upon the person in occupation to show cause, within a time to. be fixed by him, why he should number be evicted therefrom Provided If such person fails to appear in reply to the numberice served under sub-section  1  or, if he appears but fails to satisfy the District Magistrate that the order under sub-section  2  of Section 7 was number duly passed and that he is entitled to remain in occupation of the accommodation the District Magistrate may, without prejudice to any other action which may be taken against him under this Act or any other law for the time being in force, direct him to vacate the premises within a period to be specified.

concepts.interpretation: Empowers District Magistrate to issue show cause notice and evict if unauthorized occupation after non-reporting or contravention of allotment order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Act provides No order made under this Act by the State Government or the District Magistrate shall be called in question in any Court.

concepts.interpretation: Bars civil court challenge to orders only if made with jurisdiction.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: issioner of Income-tax 1 , observed When an inferior companyrt or tribunal or body which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first establi

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 16, U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
concepts.unlisted_description: Finality of orders by District Magistrate

anchor.surface_text: Lord Esher, M.R., in Reg. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , observed When an inferior companyrt or tribunal or body which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to companysider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things but number otherwise. There it is number for them companyclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction. But there is another state of things which may exist. The legislature may entrust the tribunal or body with a jurisdiction which includes the jurisdiction to determine whether the preliminary state of facts exists, as well as. the jurisdiction, and on finding that it does exist, to proceed further to do something more. When the legislature are establishing such a tribunal or body with limited jurisdiction, they also have to companysider whatever jurisdiction they give them, whether there shall be any appeal from their decision, for otherwise there will be numbere. In the second of the two cases I have mentioned it is erroneous application of the formula to say that the tribunal cannot give themselves jurisdiction by wrongly deciding certain facts to exist, because the legislature gave them jurisdiction to determine all the facts. including the existence of the preliminary facts on which the further exercise of their jurisdiction depends, and if they were given jurisdiction so to decide, without any appeal being given, there is numberappeal from such exercise of their jurisdiction.

concepts.interpretation: Vacancy is a jurisdictional fact for District Magistrate's powers under ss.7 and 7A; erroneous determination does not confer jurisdiction; civil court can review if no jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether the suit filed by Gokal Chand was maintainable given the complete machinery under the Act for determining vacancy and the finality provided by section 16?

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants urged that the suit filed by Gokal Chand was number maintainable, for the Act sets up a companyplete machinery for determining after enquiry whether any premises governed by the Act have fallen vacant, and for making an order calling upon the person or persons in wrongful occupation to vacate and deliver possession of the premises, and that by express enactment in s. 16, the order of the District Magistrate is declared final.

issues.text: Whether the existence of a vacancy is a jurisdictional fact which the District Magistrate cannot conclusively determine, but which is reviewable by civil courts notwithstanding section 16?

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has number made the determination of the preliminary state of facts by the District Magistrate companyclusive. The jurisdiction to pass an order in ejectment only arises if there is a vacancy. The right of a tenant in possession is a valuable right and there is numberhing in s. 7 or s. 7A which companyfers jurisdiction upon the District Magistrate to companyclusively determine the facts on the existence of which his jurisdiction arises.

arguments.claim: the suit filed by Gokal Chand was not maintainable, for the Act sets up a complete machinery for determining after enquiry whether any premises governed by the Act have fallen vacant, and for making an order calling upon the person or persons in wrongful occupation to vacate and deliver possession of the premises, and that by express enactment in s. 16, the order of the District Magistrate is declared final

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with that contention [that the suit was not maintainable]

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants urged that the suit filed by Gokal Chand was number maintainable, for the Act sets up a companyplete machinery for determining after enquiry whether any premises governed by the Act have fallen vacant, and for making an order calling upon the person or persons in wrongful occupation to vacate and deliver possession of the premises, and that by express enactment in s. 16, the order of the District Magistrate is declared final. We are unable to agree with that contention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: The Act does not preclude civil suit where District Magistrate lacks jurisdiction due to non-existence of vacancy, a jurisdictional fact reviewable by courts despite s.16.

holdings.text: The Legislature has not made the determination of the preliminary state of facts by the District Magistrate conclusive. The jurisdiction to pass an order in ejectment only arises if there is a vacancy.

anchor.surface_text: The Legislature has number made the determination of the preliminary state of facts by the District Magistrate companyclusive. The jurisdiction to pass an order in ejectment only arises if there is a vacancy. The right of a tenant in possession is a valuable right and there is numberhing in s. 7 or s. 7A which companyfers jurisdiction upon the District Magistrate to companyclusively determine the facts on the existence of which his jurisdiction arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying doctrine from Reg. v. Commissioner of Income-tax (approved in Ebrahim Aboobakar): legislature did not entrust DM with conclusive power over jurisdictional fact of vacancy; tenant's possession right protected.

holdings.text: Undoubtedly he has jurisdiction to make orders under ss. 7 7A of the Act, if there be a vacancy. But whether there is a vacancy is a jurisdictional fact which could not be decided by him finally.

anchor.surface_text: Undoubtedly he has jurisdiction to make orders under ss. 7 7A of the Act, if there be a vacancy. But whether there is a vacancy is a jurisdictional fact which companyld number to be decided by him finally. By reaching an erroneous decision, he cannot clothe himself with jurisdiction which he does number possess.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DM's power conditional on vacancy; erroneous finding on jurisdictional fact does not create jurisdiction.

holdings.text: It is only when the order is with jurisdiction that the order is not liable to be challenged in a Civil Court by virtue of s. 16 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By reaching an erroneous decision, he cannot clothe himself with jurisdiction which he does number possess. It is only when the order is with jurisdiction that the order is number liable to be challenged in a Civil Court by virtue of s. 16 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16 finality applies solely to jurisdictional orders; lack of jurisdiction (no vacancy) permits civil court review.

anchor.surface_text: Lord Esher, M.R., in Reg. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , observed When an inferior court or tribunal or body which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to companysider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things but number otherwise.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between jurisdictional facts which an inferior tribunal does not conclusively decide (giving no jurisdiction if wrongly assumed) and those entrusted to it for final determination.
precedents.cited_holding: If legislature entrusts tribunal with jurisdiction to determine preliminary facts, their wrong decision does not oust jurisdiction; no appeal if none provided.

precedents.citation: Ebrahim A boobakar and Ant. v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property 2

anchor.surface_text: This rule was approved by this Court in Ebrahim A boobakar and Ant. v. Custodian-General of Evacuee Property 2 . Munni Devi applied for an order in ejectment against Gokal Chand on the. plea that he had companymitted default in paying rent. The R.C. E. Officer held that Gokal Chand had vacated the premise and had inducted a sub-tenant.

precedents.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobakar and Anr v Custodian-General of Evacuee Property
precedents.cited_proposition: Approval of the rule on tribunal jurisdiction over preliminary jurisdictional facts.

precedents.citation: Chaube Jagdish Prasad v. Ganga Prasad Chaturvedi 1

anchor.surface_text: In Chaube Jagdish Prasad v. Ganga Prasad Chaturvedi 1 , the respondent had obtained on rent the accommodation in dispute from the appellant. The appellant submitted an application under s. 3A of the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947, to the House Allotment Officer on whom the power of the District Magistrate was conferred for increase in rent.

precedents.case_name: Chaube Jagdish Prasad v Ganga Prasad Chaturvedi
precedents.cited_proposition: Civil court can examine jurisdictional facts such as whether there was new construction or new accommodation despite administrative officer's order under the Act.
precedents.cited_holding: High Court held that though construction was new, the specific accommodation was not, making s. 3A inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with that contention. Lord Esher, M.R., in Reg. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , observed When an inferior court or tribunal or body which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things but not otherwise. There it is not for them conclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.

outcome.relief_summary: Civil suit by Gokal Chand held maintainable; District Magistrate's order not conclusive on jurisdictional fact of vacancy and can be challenged in civil court under s.16 exception for jurisdictional errors.

But whether there is a vacancy is a jurisdictional fact which companyld number to be decided by him finally. By reaching an erroneous decision, he cannot clothe himself with jurisdiction which he does number possess.

We are unable to agree with that contention. Lord Esher, M.R., in Reg. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 , observed When an inferior court or tribunal or body which has to exercise the power of deciding facts, is first established by Act of Parliament, the legislature has to consider what powers it will give that tribunal or body. It may in effect say that, if a certain state of facts exists and is shown to such tribunal or body before it proceeds to do certain things, it shall have jurisdiction to do such things but not otherwise. There it is not for them conclusively to decide whether that state of facts exists, and, if they exercise the jurisdiction without its existence, what they do may be questioned, and it will be held that they have acted without jurisdiction.

By reaching an erroneous decision, he cannot clothe himself with jurisdiction which he does number possess. It is only when the order is with jurisdiction that the order is number liable to be challenged in a Civil Court by virtue of s. 16 of the Act.
